results.name: Triangle of derivatives of the Niven polynomials evaluated at 0.
comment: The Niven potentials N(n, x) = (1/n!)*x^n*(1 - x)^n = Sum_{k=0..n} (-1)^k * x^(n+k)/((n-k)!*k!), with (n-k)!*k! = A098361(n, k), are used to prove the irrationality of Pi^2 (hence Pi). See the Niven and Havil references.

The row polynomials R(n, x) = Sum_{k=0..n} T(n, k) *x^k are R(n, x) = y_n(-2*x), with the Bessel polynomials of Krall and Frink y_n(x) with coefficients given in A001498. There the references are given. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, May 12 2018
reference: Julian Havil, The Irrationals, Princeton University Press, Princeton and Oxford, 2012, pp. 116-125.
Ivan Niven, Irrational Numbers, Math. Assoc. Am., John Wiley and Sons, New York, 2nd printing 1963, pp. 19-21.
formula: N^{(n+k)}(n, 1) = (-1)^(n+k)*T(n, k), which has for even n the unsigned rows, and for odd n the unsigned row entries with negative signs.
T(n, k) = (-1)^k*Pochhammer(n+1, k)*binomial(n, k). - _Peter Luschny_, May 11 2018

Recurrence: from the one of the row polynomials R(n, x) = y_n(-2*x): R(n, x) = -2*(2*n-1)*x*R(n-1, x) + R(n-2, x), with R(-1, x) = 1 = R(0, x) = 1, n >= 1 (see A001498), this becomes, for n >= 0, k = 0..n:
T(n, k) = 0 for n < k, T(n, -1) = 0, T(0, 0) = 1 = T(1, 0) and otherwise
T(n, k) = -2*(2*n-1)*T(n-1, k-1) + T(n-2, k). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, May 12 2018
maple: seq(print(seq(T(n, k), k=0..n)), n=0..9); # _Peter Luschny_, May 11 2018
